as well as parodying video games themselves."

other civil rights, they would not have allowed anybody to circumvent those

Not necessarily to defend the NSA, but it isn't within the NSAs purview to 
intervene on subjects like this. If the NSA was spying domestically to 
prevent crimes, Ana and the rest of TYT would flip their shit. As for 
whether or not these programs have legitimate use for counter terrorism, I 
don't think we'll ever know that, because honestly they would never publish 
reports of how these things worked. It would be like the police saying yeah 
we tapped x pay phones and we caught y criminals. Well, you can be assured 
that criminals aren't going to use those pay phones or any pay phones. And 
now you've got to spend millions of dollars finding new ways to catch 
someone.

understood what they've been up to. There absolutely is a balance, but the 
idea that the NSA is listening to every conversation simply makes no sense.

theory.

I'd suggest we have a lot more immediate problems in terms of the growing

Actually, Ana, as a rule, people with Autism Spectrum Disorders have been 
shown to be much more sensitive to others than "normal" people, just less 
able to communicate their sensitivity. All Asperger's means is that they do 
not learn social cues automatically like people without ASDs, they like 
repetitive work, they tend to have an interest they primarily focus on, use 
language in a way that is atypical to non-Aspies (verbosity, abrupt 
transitions, literal interpretations and miscomprehension of nuance, use of 
metaphor meaningful only to the speaker, etc). The shooting itself had 
nothing to do with being disturbed because of the Asperger's in itself.﻿

TYT, when did you stop critical thinking? While it is a bit disturbing, 
none of what Lanza said here is outside the realm of curiosity and thought. 
We obviously know that there was something deeper going on with Lanza, but 
otherwise, it simply sounds like contemplation on modern society, something 
I don't think there's enough of. Now, all the other stuff, and the fact 
that he called an Anarchist radio show to speak this is disturbing. But 
Lanza made a good point about society.

The chimp is an interesting parallel because it's an animal, something we 
generally think of as wild, but it was also a domesticated pet and one that 
people often thought of as nice and friendly. Until this incident happened. 
Likewise, people can do certain things for which we have no real 
explanation. We can't know what Lanza was thinking when he did what he did, 
but he certainly did make real exactly what he was talking about  in that 
interview: no one would have suspected that he would carry out such an act. 
Who could have? Even with red flags and all the help in the world, without 
knowing the cause of why Lanza did what he did, how could this have been 
prevented? Like the chimp, he committed a random act of violence that no 
one saw coming.

I don't think it's crazy or a red flag to ponder this aspect of humanity. 
In fact, I'd say it's insightful to view humans as animals with the 
potential to defy expectations and act randomly. I also think that, what he 
means in his remarks about civilization make sense in a certain way of 
seeing society. We, as humanity, are wild creatures who are taught to be 
civilized. It's not something we know, it's not something ingrained in us, 
it's something we're taught. Which is why civilization, from place to 
place, differs. There are similarities and there are differences. It sounds 
like, maybe, Lanza was frustrated with something, or fascinated by the 
idea. The fact that he mentions children in his interview is a parallel to 
what he did as well. I think that, for as crazy as we want to make Lanza 
out to be, and he very likely was, he also seems like he was perceptive and 
had a lot going on in his head in terms of thinking about society. It seems 
to me that you guys are simply dismissing this because he was a crazy dude 
who shot up kids.﻿

If I understand what you say, I am in full agreement with you. I would also 
like to add that Lanza's radio statements, in addition to being rather 
common place, sound a lot like the words of the philosopher Thomas Hobbes 
who, far as I know, was not a violent man. He was expressing a world 
view honestly held by many people who even though they would prefer peace 
any day.

Now, Lanza did use some violent imagery, but I don't think that should be 
read too much into. Violence was the topic, after all, but more than that 
one should consider his ostensible Aspergers. Aspergers doesn't make a 
person violent, but it does make reading the style or subtext of that 
person's words problematic. Aspies have a tendency towards using 
"inappropriate" subjects to support a message that is perfectly 
appropriate. A lot of things like subtext, tone, emotional imagery, body 
language and even sarcasm, which most people grasp intuitively, Aspies 
have to get intellectually. Kind of a mute point with Lanza, who did turn 
violent, but it is perfectly possible that he wasn't using the chimp event 
or shootings for dramatic effect or anything other than to support his 
viewpoint. That is to say, he could have been drawing on emotional subjects 
only for the intellectual content he could glean from them.

Lanza did make some sense in his interview. The "chimp like state" he 
referred to is the uncivilized state. Children aren't born capable of 
comprehending all of the complexities of society, they are raised in it 
and, as a result, learn it. A human baby and a monkey are equally capable 
of responding to the world up to a certain age, where the child surpasses 
the chimp and continues to advance.

This being said, some people are born "crazy" and never become civilized. 
We don't know how to clearly define what is wrong with them in all cases, 
but they sometimes act in a violent way. Can't those people be compared to 
wild animals, compelled to act violently toward an end that we do not 
share? If a guy shoots up a school, can't we, to some degree, consider him 
to be like a boa who eats a man or a dog who attacks a child, only pausing 
to add in that there are "civilized" people who hunt and trap animals for 
fun? A person who can kill for fun, like a hunter, and does not have strong 
ties to humanity, like a nonhuman animal, can act upon his nature and kill 
a large group of people for fun (unlike the snake who kills out of hunger 
or the dog who attacks out of territory or self defense).This is not a 
feeling I hold personally, but one I can perceive in others. A crazy, 
socio/psychopathic, delusional, unstable animal can harm a group of like 
animals with no regard for the consequences. Humans are just animals, after 
all.

So, back to Lanza's point, why is it that the violent acts of the human 
animal deserve more publicity than the violent acts of a nonhuman animal? 

I think it's because we are humans and get more emotionally invested in 
humans, killers or otherwise, than we get in an animal. It's the same 
reason we personify so many things. (Mother Earth and Gaia, el 
escritorio/"desk" is masculine in Spanish, Anansi the Spider/Papa Bear, 
etc)﻿

option that can induce any kind of strong emotional response.  If we want

and blaming that person.  We don't like to see ourselves as deterministic 
elements of the universe, but we are.  If you want to find the source of 
blame for Lanza's actions you have to look at what happened in his 
childhood that fostered the disturbed mental condition he was in that 
concluded violence was the best option.

Aspergers is not the sort of diagnosis that would preclude you from having 
a gun. It mostly has to do with how a person processes information. Someone 
who is terrible with non-verbal communication though likely very good on 
the details of something that strikes their interest. Physically and 
socially awkward. It's a disorder mostly in that it makes communication 
with others confusing for both parties. Those with Aspergers tend to be 
more literal in their communication, both in what they say and how they 
interpret others. Connecting Aspergers and the shooting is basically saying 
that weird people are dangerous. If they ever are it would probably be best 
attributed to folks treating them like second class citizens.

From Wikipedia: "The hypothesis that individuals with AS are predisposed to 
violent or criminal behavior has been investigated, but is not supported by 
data. More evidence suggests children with AS are victims rather than 
victimizers."

If you meet someone who says they have Aspergers, please do not act scared 
and certainly don't zone them out as if everything they have to say comes 
from a disturbed or delusional mind. If anything pay closer attention to 
what they say and how you speak because there's a risk of confusion.﻿

+Bourgeoisie Liberal There's a great deal of arrogance in the statement 
that anarchists cannot answer the question as to how rules will be created 
and enforced once the "government" is dismantled. First of all, this is not 
addressing anarchism, since anarchism does not reject the idea that we 
ought to have social organization, governance. It is the rejection to the 
assertion that some individuals ought to have greater power over others 
within social organization. Secondly, to say that after several centuries 
of thought, hundreds of books written and an actual, living historical 
example of mass scale anarchism, anarchists cannot answer these basic 
questions is quite frankly extremely intellectually dishonest. To read more 
on the subject, I again recommend to you another reading composed by 
anarchist writers with citations to anarchist literature, specifically 
addressing theory: http://www.infoshop.org/AnarchistFAQSectionI5
The historical example would be Anarcho-syndicalist Catalonia, Barcelona 
and other cities which were syndicated during the Spanish Revolution. In 
addition to the book I recommended earlier would be the documentary, 
'Living Utopia', which takes the viewer through several first hand accounts 
of what happened. Orwell also spoke extremely highly of anarchist Catalonia 
in his book "Homage to Catalonia".

+Bourgeoisie Liberal You demonstrate within your own comment how this can 
be seen as propaganda, since you use the word Anarchism to refer to "an 
irrational fear of the government". The author of the original comment 
suggested that this video published by TYT is propaganda specifically 
because it is furthering a false description of the political philosophy 
and here we are seen with an example of an individual, yourself, speaking 
about anarchism in an extremely idiosyncratic manner. Throughout your 
comment, the insinuation is made that anarchism is synonymous with 
right-wing radical libertariansim in which capitalism is left totally alone 
without statist intervention. This is, of course, another example of the 
effect of propaganda and Orwellian double-speak. 

To clarify the points made by anarchism, it is not the belief that without 
government, there would exist no social hierarchy. It is a common 
misconception that anarchists oppose governance, but that is completely 
ridiculous since anarchism itself is a method of organization, a method of 
governance. It is not government that anarchists reject, but the idea of a 
state, which every anarchist holds to be synonymous with the idea of 
capitalism. In essence, it is the concept that someone ought to have 
control over matters which are none of his/her concern through the 
domination of property. A capitalist's domination of capital, justified by 
nothing more substantive than the employment of armed thugs, is as equally 
wrong as a state's domination of a land, justified by nothing more 
substantive than the employment of armed thugs. 

You claim that without government, power would ultimately fall in the hands 
of the very wealthy, and that's why anarchism fails as a political 
ideology. This is quite a funny statement since practically every single 
anarchist would agree with you here. The rich and powerful do not have some 
innate power, rather, their power is derived from a statist control of 
resources. Anarchists do not just seek to collapse the state and still 
retain capitalism, as though they are separate entities. Rather, anarchism 
was literally founded as an anti-statist method of achieving socialism, 
worker's self-management. It is merely the belief that socialism is 
possible and desirable but cannot be achieved through statist appropriation 
of capital and property. To see what anarchists actually want and not what 
the great propagandists tell you we want, I recommend the book "The 
Anarchist Collectives" by Murray Bookchin since it documents how two 
million anarchists syndicated and organized society in Spain during the 
Spanish Civil War. They retained an anarchist method of governance without 
a state or capitalism.

+John Connor The behavioral differences in psychopathy and Asperger's are 
complex.  With psychopathy, there exists a lack of emotional connection 
with others but the individual is still capable of understanding quite well 
how the emotions of other people work in various situations.  Asperger's 
individuals are not incapable of feeling emotions, they simply cannot 
understand the context or general meaning of when/why emotions are 
expressed.  This is what leads to the emotional detachment which combined 
with lack of positive experiences can lead someone in either group to 
commit acts of violence.

It was an obvious misdiagnosis. People with Asperger's usually have a more 
difficult time empathizing and so Adam's anti-social and unsympathetic 
nature was likely attributed to that, when in reality he was a psychopath.

Asperger's is a very broad condition which has core symptoms of a 
detachment from the typical level of emotional and mental connection 
healthy individuals experience with others in society.  Lanza at that point 
in his life had a complete inability to connect with other humans, and most 
likely felt as if he were a Travis being driven around and conditioned by 
his mother to appear as a "sweet child."  His mother did not understand his 
condition, as evidenced by other reports, and did not give him the 
unconditional love, support, and counseling that is necessary for someone 
with Asperger's to foster an emotional connection with other humans.  On an 
emotional level, Lanza did not see the people he killed or that other mass 
shooters had killed as being independent conscious beings, and thus did not 
have a typical repulsion to ending their lives as any healthy individual 
would have.  Not all people who have Asperger's resort to mass violence 
such as Lanza in the absence of proper care, but many do end up homeless or 
resorting to criminal activity.  It is ultimately the responsibility of the 
care takers to unconditionally love and take special care of Asperger's 
children, because in the end we all only behave as our brain chemistry 
dictates.  Bottom line is: we need better public education about mental 
health, both in understanding the conditions that can occur and in how to 
care for a child or relative who has these conditions.
